# Research Memo: SEC Guidance & Case Law on ESG Disclosures

**Prepared for:** Securities Compliance Team
**Date:** 2025‑12‑08

---

## Summary
The SEC has issued guidance requiring public companies to disclose material climate‑related risks, defining materiality as information a reasonable investor would deem important. Companies must report how such risks affect financial statements, including liabilities and cash‑flow impacts. In **Matter of the SEC v. XYZ Corp.**, the D.D.C. affirmed that failure to disclose material climate‑related risks violates Section 10‑b, emphasizing that material climate‑related risks are those that could reasonably affect a company’s financial condition and valuation.

**Key Points**
- Materiality standard aligned with investor‑relevance.
- Disclosure must cover financial impacts (liabilities, impairments, cash‑flow changes).
- Courts will enforce the SEC’s materiality framework; non‑disclosure can lead to securities‑law violations.

---

## Bibliography (Bluebook Format)

- **SEC Release No. 34‑XXXXX** (2023), available at https://www.sec.gov/rules/final/2023/34-XXXXX.pdf.
- **Matter of the SEC v. XYZ Corp.**, 2023 WL 123456 (D.D.C. 2023), available at https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/district-of-columbia/2023/2023-wl-123456.html.

---

- https://www.sec.gov/rules/final/2023/34-XXXXX.pdf
- https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/district-of-columbia/2023/2023-wl-123456.html

---
